structural_unit_name.en: Johan Skytte Institute of Political Studies

description.en: The course is thematically divided into two parts the first part offers a broad overview of the historical developments in the Baltic Sea Region, including both domestic as well international developments in the region. The second half of the course focuses on conflicting narratives in the region and thereby the course develops critical approach towards national and panregional narratives.
description.et: Kursus on jagatud temaatiliselt kaheks osaks. Esimene pool kursusest annab ülevaate Läänemere regiooni ajaloost ja peamistest siseriiklikest ja riikidevaheliste suhete arengutest. Kursuse teine osa keskendub regioonis olevatele konfliktsetele narratiividele, arendades seeläbi kriitilist käsitlust erinevate rahvuslike ja regiooniüleste narratiivide suhtes.

objectives.en: The course aims to provide an overview of the historical development of the nations of the Baltic Sea Region (Denmark, Estonia, Finland, Germany, Latvia, Lithuania, Norway, Poland, Russia) within a broad regional context from the Stone Age to the enlargement of the EU in 2004. Furthermore, the course aims to develop a critical analysis of historical narratives and understandings of clashes based on conflicting narratives in the region.
objectives.et: Kursuse eesmärgiks on anda ülevaade Läänemere regiooni ajaloolisest kujunemisest ning selle rahvaste ajaloolistest arengutest viikingite ajast Euroopa Liidu laienemiseni 2004. Samuti on kursuse eesmärgiks arendada kriitilist ajaloonarratiivide analüüsi ning vastolulistest narratiividest tekkivate konfliktide mõistmist Läänemere regioonis.

learning_outcomes.en: Upon completion of the course, the student:
- defines and describes main historical periods of the Baltic Sea nations and names key events in their history;
learning_outcomes.et: - määratleb ja kirjeldab Läänemere maade rahvaste peamisi ajalooetappe ja nimetab neis olulisemad võtmesündmused;

learning_outcomes.en: - characterises and compares development of statehood in the Baltic Sea region during different historical periods;
learning_outcomes.et: - iseloomustab ja võrdleb Läänemere maade riikluse kujunemist erinevatel ajalooetappidel;

learning_outcomes.en: - characterises and compares development of international relations in the Baltic Sea regional context during different historical periods;
learning_outcomes.et: - iseloomustab ja võrdleb Läänemere maade regionaalseid suhteid erinevatel ajalooetappidel;

learning_outcomes.en: - characterises socioeconomic developments in the Baltic Sea region during different historical periods;
learning_outcomes.et: - iseloomustab peamisi sotsiaalmajanduslikke arenguid Läänemere regioonis erinevatel ajalooetappidel;

learning_outcomes.en: - compares and understand different history perspectives and narratives in the Baltic Sea region.
learning_outcomes.et: - võrdleb ja mõistab erinevaid ajalooperspektiive ja -narratiive Läänemere regioonis.

independent_work.et:
Students are expected to work through independently Moodle online lessons and read assigned chapters from the compulsory reading materials. Furthermore, students are welcomed to look at additional information from recommended readings in order to write reflection papers.

Student should write an individual critical analysis. 

The course has an oral final exam that will be based on online lessons and compulsory readings.

Further guidelines available in Moodle.

description.et: You have to submit five reflection papers. Your reflection papers will be assessed either accepted or resubmit. The course instructor pays attention to two aspects: - comprehensiveness and thoroughness of the reflection - factual correctness of the reflection Deadlines: September 25, October 9, October 23, November 6, November 20 Meaning of the result "Accepted" - it is a comprehensive and thorough analysis, it covers the most important elements/topics of the historical period. It demonstrates a good understanding of the political, international and socio-economic processes during the historical period. There are few factual mistakes, but they do not lead to wrong conclusions. This result means that the reflection counts as one required successful submission. Meaning of the result "Resubmit" - it is a too superficial overview and/or does not cover some essential elements/topics of the historical period, it does not demonstrate a solid understanding of the political, international and socio-economic processes during the historical period but it is instead a fragmented pile of facts and/or there are too many factual mistakes that (may) lead to wrong conclusions.

Periodisation of the Baltic Sea region history

A - the main historical periods of the Baltic Sea region are clearly and independently defined; they are thoroughly described, the periodisation is thoroughly argued, using the key events and their meaning in the context of the history of the Baltic Sea region; various alternatives, including the periodisation proposed in the lessons, are thoroughly and convincingly discussed
B - the main historical periods of the Baltic Sea region are clearly defined and thoroughly described, the periodisation is thoroughly argued, using the key events and their meaning in the context of the history of the Baltic Sea region, periodisation mentions possible alternatives without discussing them thoroughly
C - the main historical periods of the Baltic Sea region are clearly defined and thoroughly described, the periodisation is well-argued, using the key events and their meaning in the context of the history of the Baltic Sea region
D - the main historical periods of the Baltic Sea region are clearly defined and described, the key events are mentioned, and their importance is used to explain the periodisation
E - the main historical periods of the Baltic Sea region are clearly defined and sufficiently described, including the key events within the periods
F - does not meet the minimal criteria

NB! Papers where has been found plagiarism will fail automatically and the student would fail the entire course without the right to have resit during the ongoing semester.

Critical analysis

See the detailed assessment matrix in Moodle.

NB! Papers where has been found plagiarism will fail automatically and the student would fail the entire course without the right to have resit during the ongoing semester.
See the detailed assessment matrix in Moodle. Exam dates January 09 OR 16.

grade_preconditions.et:
Students should attend all seminars, in the case, the participation is not possible, the student should contribute towards a group work task.
 
Students should submit all five reflection papers, and they should be prepared on the pass level (in the case of an initial fail result, there is a possibility to resubmit the paper). 

Students should collaborate and deliver for the joint class presentation.

grade_evaluation.et:
The periodisation of the Baltic Sea region history - 20%
Critical analysis - 20%
Final exam - (20+20+20) 60%

debt_elimination.et: All the reflection papers should be resubmitted (if need be) NLT December 4.

assessment_scale.et: Eristav (A, B, C, D, E, F, mi)
assessment_scale.en: differentiated (A, B, C, D, E, F, not present)

description.et: Independent study: From Nomadic Hunters to Merchants: history from the Ice Age to the Middle Ages (September 05-September 18)
Early history and Middle Ages in the Baltic Sea region
Independent study: Modernizing states and the Northern Wars: Early Modern Era (16th-early 18th century) (September 26-October 02)
Early Modernization in the Baltic Sea region
Independent study: Big Empires and Small Nations in Modernization: Modern Era (18th-early 20th century) (October 10-16)
Modernization in the Baltic Sea region
Independent study: End of the Imperial Era and Triumph of Era of Ideologies: 1914-1945 (October 24-October 30)
Independent study: Rise and Fall of the Ideological Frontline: 1945 and beyond (November 07-13)
Divided and reunited Baltic Sea region
Weeks 13 and 14 are meant for individual or group consultations to prepare your group presentation and/or revise your reflection papers and clarify materials for the final exam.
Critical Analysis of Competing Narratives vol 1
Critical Analysis of Competing Narratives vol 2
